nodes.bodyText: We should do delegate.close(cause); before ctx.request().abort(cause);

It seems like canceling the response timeout to me. Should we rename the TimeoutScheduler? 🤔
/cc @ikhoon

I think cancel() is clearer about the behavior we want. Having a cancel(), isCancelled() pair looks better. Also I don't think we need to pass the cause around, the TimeoutTask can determine it in one place. But I agree on renaming TimeoutScheduler to something more general 😄
Don't we need to introduce RequestCancellationException and make it singletone?
Is it better to move these methods down to ClientRequestContext? 🤔
Don't we need to complete whenTimingOut and whenTimedOut even if it is cancelled? Unless the futures never complete forever.
How about calling cancel() the futures?
That sounds nice. Could you reuse cacelled futures if users don’t call whenTime*out yet to avoid additional memory allocation?
Aren't the futures null when users haven't called whenTim*out?
Oh sure 😁

This is not thread safe and could override the original cause if a request was cancelled already.
Question: Do we need to save cancellationCause in this class?

But client uses ResponseTimeoutException and service uses RequestTimeoutException. We can check cause == null when it's consumed and resolve to either ResponseTimeoutException or RequestTimeoutException, but I think that's more code ... 😄
